title: Sexual practices and repertoires of young people in the UK
abstractText:
The UK's record on teenage pregnancies and sexually transmitted infections has historically been poor, and public health responses focused narrowly on penetrative intercourse.

The sixteen18 project explored sexual practices among young people, aiming to look beyond vaginal intercourse – the focus of most previous research - to a wider range of sexual activities and their meanings for young people, including manual, oral and anal practices.

We conducted conversational interviews with 130 16-to-18-year-olds in three diverse locations in England (London, a northern city and an area in the southwest), both one-to-one and in groups. We also conducted follow-up one-to-one interviews with 43 of them a year later.

The findings provide a rich picture of young people’s sexual lives and the factors that influence them - including gender dynamics, coercion and other societal influences - that will be useful to educators and policymakers.
impactText: Our findings have contributed to theory and understanding of young people's sexual practices. We have spoken to numerous practitioners about our findings both formally via conferences and meetings and informally in other settings. Our findings have been covered in national and international media and have reached the public. Members of the public have contacted us directly to us to discuss our work, and have provided commentary on the work via BBC radio 4 and on numerous internet sites. This has particularly been the case for our work on coercive sexual activity and we hope to continue these conversations in future. Communities and Social Services/Policy,Education,Healthcare,Government, Democracy and Justice,Culture, Heritage, Museums and Collections Cultural,Societal
organisation: London Sch of Hygiene and Trop Medicine
